metadata.notes: The text is fragmentary with X indicating a damaged or unclear sign. "i" typically refers to oil (i3 in Sumerian). "ukim" appears to be a personal name. The overall structure suggests this is part of an administrative record, possibly listing oil associated with or belonging to a person named Ukim.

This is a standard administrative formula indicating a sealed document. "kicib" (kišib) means "seal" or "sealed document," and "urnigar" (Ur-nigar) is a personal name meaning "servant of Nigar" or similar. This formula is extremely common in Ur III administrative texts to indicate authorization or receipt.

The phrase "kinbi" (kin-bi) means "its work" where "kin" = work/task and "-bi" is a possessive suffix. "sar" is a unit of area measurement (approximately 36 square meters). This is a common administrative notation indicating the amount of work measured in sar units.

The term "u" typically means "day" in administrative contexts. "sagnigura" appears to be a compound term, likely referring to a festival or ritual occasion (sag-nig-gur-ra). This type of temporal marker is common in Ur III administrative texts to indicate when offerings or transactions took place.

The term "u" typically means "day" in Sumerian administrative texts. "mucbian" appears to be a compound referring to a night watch or night time period (muš = night, bian possibly related to time/watch). This phrase likely indicates a specific time notation in an administrative record.

Standard Ur III administrative formula. "ki" means "place/from" when used with the ablative suffix "-ta", and "Budu" is a personal name. This follows the common pattern seen in examples like "ki abasagata" (from Abbasaga) and "ki amarcubata" (from Amar-šuba).

This is the name of the famous Sumerian hero-king Gilgamesh, legendary ruler of Uruk. The name appears in cuneiform texts as a divine or semi-divine figure, central to Mesopotamian epic literature including the Epic of Gilgamesh.

The structure follows the common Ur III year name pattern: mu + event description + ba-du3 (was built).

This is a standard Ur III period patronymic formula. "u" here functions as a dative marker (for), "lugalbaba" is a personal name meaning "Lugal is (my) father", "dumu" means "son of", and "urlamma" is another personal name meaning "Ur-lamma" (servant/man of Lamma).
